revision.text: ==English== ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|UK}} {{IPA|en|/jɑːk/}} * {{rhymes|en|ɑː(ɹ)k|s=1}} ===Etymology 1=== From {{inh|en|enm|ȝarken}}, {{m|enm|ȝerken}}, from {{inh|en|ang|ġearcian||to prepare, make ready, procure, furnish, supply}}, from {{inh|en|gem-pro|*garwakōną||to prepare}}, from {{der|en|ine-pro|*gʰrebʰ-||to grab, take, rake}}, equivalent to {{suffix|en|yare|k|nocat=1}}. Related to {{cog|ang|ġearc||ready, active, quick}}, {{m|ang|ġearu||prepared, ready, equipped, complete, finished, yare}}. More at {{l|en|yare}}. ====Verb==== {{en-verb}} # {{lb|en|transitive|UK|_|dialectal}} To make [[ready]]; [[prepare]]. #* '''1881''', Walter Gregor, ''Notes on the Folk-Lore of the North-East of Scotland'': #*: [...] Yet thou hast given us leather to '''yark''', and leather to bark, [...] # {{lb|en|transitive|obsolete}} To [[dispose]]; be set in order for; be destined or intended for. # {{lb|en|transitive|obsolete}} To set open; [[open]]. =====Derived terms===== * {{l|en|yarking}} ===Etymology 2=== Origin uncertain, probably originally imitative; compare {{m|en|jerk}} etc. ====Alternative forms==== * [[yerk]] ====Verb==== {{en-verb}} # To draw (stitches etc.) tight. # To [[hit]], [[strike]], especially with a [[cane]] or [[whip]]. # To [[crack]] (a whip). #* {{RQ:Montaigne Florio Essayes}}, Folio Society, 2006, vol.1, p.96: #*: he would throw a Dagger, and make a whip to '''yarke''' and lash [''tr. faisoit [[craqueter]]''], as cunningly as any Carter in ''France''. ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=akry|Kary|Kray|Kyra|aryk|kary-|kray}} ---- ==Yola== ===Etymology=== Perhaps cognate with {{cog|en|ark||A large box}}. ===Noun=== {{head|yol|noun}} # [[barn]] ===References=== * {{R:Poole 1867|page=79}}
